Award.AwardTitle: NSWP: Poynting and Kinetic-Energy Flux Derived from the FAST Satellite: an Empirical Model
Award.AbstractNarration: The primary purpose of this project is to develop improved models of the energy input from the magnetosphere to the thermosphere at high latitudes using five years of data from the Fast Auroral Snapshot Explorer (FAST) satellite. Such information is important for accurate modeling and specification of the thermospheric neutral densities and circulation and is a necessary input for space weather models. The methodology involves fitting a model directly to measurements of the energy input derived from FAST satellite observations with good time and space resolution. More than 20,000 satellite orbits are available for analysis. The data will be binned according to geophysical parameters. An analytical model based on a low order spherical harmonic expansion will then be fit to the binned data. The model will provide spatial maps of the average energy input and predictions of the energy input as a function of scale size in two dimensions for particular values of model parameters. The energy arriving from the magnetosphere is mostly in the form of Poynting flux traveling along magnetic field lines and partially converted to kinetic energy in the auroral acceleration region. Separate models of the relative spatial distribution of kinetic energy and Poynting flux below the auroral acceleration region will also be produced. The particular science question being addressed is whether the localization of energy inputs in the auroral region is imposed by the magnetosphere or is affected by the auroral acceleration region. If the latter mechanism is important, investigation will be made of whether the auroral acceleration region broadens the spatial extent of the region of greatest energy input. The project has several broader impacts: The models produced will quantify the energy budget for solar-wind-driven heating of the thermosphere, in both the spatial and spatial frequency domains. Energy convergence and conversion in the auroral acceleration region will be quantified using in-situ measurements. The models will be made available to the community and can be used to drive models of the global temperature, circulation, and density of the thermosphere, the specification of which is a key goal of the National Space Weather Program. A large part of the research will be performed by senior undergraduate students from Worcester Polytechnic Institute.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In addition to heating Earth's atmosphere with the light it produces, the sun heats Earth's atmosphere through the aurora. Although this effect is small by comparison, characterizing it is important for accurate prediction of weather in the thin upper-atmosphere surrounding satellites, and for prediction of long-term climate, where small effects can add up to alter circulation patterns that determine where global warming will be most severe. In this research project, we incorporate data from the scientific satellite Fast Auroral Snapshot Explorer (FAST) into a practical model that predicts the amount and distribution of auroral heating.

In addition to producing the tool which is the model, the research project addressed the mechanisms by which the aurora heats Earth's atmosphere. A new mechanism has been identified, associated with direct entry of charged particles from the sun. Earth's geomagnetic field generally shields Earth's surface from bombardment by charged particles emanating from the sun. This protection from the "solar wind" is thought necessary to sustain life. However, Earth's geomagnetic field has what is known as a cusp, which is similar to the little swirl made by your hair somewhere near the top of your head. Just as a drop of water can easily penetrate to your scalp through the swirl, our results have shown that there is a significant contribution to auroral heating coming through the cusp in Earth's geomagnetic field. In addition, we have verified the importance of what are known as the auroral electrojets, which are features more directly associated with the visible aurora.

The research has been conducted by researchers at SRI International, in collaboration with seven undergraduate students from Worcester Polytechnic Institute (WPI), through WPI's Major Qualifying Project program. Images of the model output, showing the distribution of auroral heating about the north magnetic pole, can be seen in the figure, where the numbers in the top left corners of the panels indicate the total auroral heating in gigawatts, and the numbers at top center indicate the angles made by Earth's geomagnetic field with respect to the magnetic field produced by the sun. The northern magnetic pole is at the center of the panels, upward is toward the sun, dawn is to the right, dusk to the left, and midnight downward. The cusp signature is especially clear in the top center panel. At present, the public can try out the model at http://spaceweathermodels.sri.com/, although it is expected that the model will eventually be hosted by the Community Coordinated Modeling Center.
